text:
Approximately 10 months ago I started an 
experiment: to explore what it would be like

to live and work for 300 days on the road. 
It would be poetic to say that this started

from a love of van life or radical minimalism, 
but this was born from chaos and disruption.

I am self-isolating in a one-bedroom 
apartment for an indefinite period of time.

I've just had my second 
flight to Australia cancelled

And along the way i discovered some 
unexpected things about creativity,
motivation and success. This is what i learned.

This video is sponsored by Merck KGAa 
Darmstadt Germany and their new survey

on human progress. Because to be honest, 
all big experiments need some support.

We tend to live our lives in pretty tight 
patterns, cycles, routines. So I have a

question for you: how did the chaos caused 
by the covid 19 pandemic upend yours? For me,

March 2020 was a month that felt like a 
year and one i'll probably never forget.

I was in new york city, the center of it all! And 
to be honest it sucked. The pattern of my life had

been upended. For six months i barely left my 
apartment and this had a huge effect on my work

and life. I felt stuck, both physically and 
mentally and I was anxious (more than normal),

I couldn't sleep, I found myself procrastinating 
and not wanting to get out of bed to start work.

The most overwhelming impact of the 
pandemic was that all of my work and

life were confined to the same four walls. 
And then I wondered, what if i just left?

In 1926 Henry Ford started the nine-to-five five 
day work week. Manufacturing cars and other goods

relied on workers to be physically on an assembly 
line for 40 hours a week. Of course many jobs

still require a physical location, but for the 
rest of us this model is an antiquated relic from

the past. And now we've been forced to radically 
rethink how and where we work. And I thought,

what would happen if i had no fixed address? 
What if i tried to work from anywhere? It would

be a big physical change, but I was more concerned 
with the mental change. I had a lot of questions:

would it be more stressful? Would I be 
unproductive working in random airbnbs? Would it

be inconvenient or annoying not having all of my 
stuff? Was I becoming a privileged digital nomad

without self-awareness who would end up moving 
into a hyatt? Would all of this make the impact

of the pandemic on my workload worse? But like all 
experiments, you never know until you try. In the

US I wasn't under any lockdowns and there were no 
travel restrictions. So I bought a car, packed it

with most of my stuff, handed back the keys to 
my dream apartment, and headed to the desert.

According to the research there are lots 
of benefits to a change of scenery, but

i was skeptical. I'm a skeptical person! Would 
I experience any of these benefits? In research,

working from a vacation 
destination is called bleisure,

which is possibly one of the worst 
portmanteaus I have ever come across.

An interview based study found that people do it 
to escape their daily routine, build skills from

new experiences and just for enjoyment. Another 
interview based study of digital nomads found

that they often built identities and lifestyles 
that didn't revolve around work. More generally,

going to new places improves mood and 
being outside has been shown to reduce

anxiety and rumination, improve working memory 
and boost creative problem-solving abilities.

But i still wondered if all of this would 
solve my problems, or if I'd just get new ones.

Now that i'm 300 days in, it was time for some 
results: essentially to ask more questions.

So another question for you: how is your work 
culture affected by the pandemic? How is your

motivation affected? The one thing that was most 
unexpected was how it affected my motivation.

When i was in new york city i was just kind of 
going through the motions, and because I was still

working I hadn't considered my attitude towards 
work. But as soon as I left I was so creatively

motivated, I had so many ideas for different 
types of videos that I just wanted to do more

stuff. I hadn't considered what it would 
mean for my anxiety levels and my self-esteem

because as soon as I left new york I 
stopped questioning myself and saying,

"am I successful? Am I doing enough 
work?" And that kind of energy of

the city that you really feed on and for 
me makes me quite anxious disappeared.

Now these questions i've been asking you like how 
was your motivation affected are inspired by the

human progress survey. So unlike my personal 
experiment of the past 300 days, this is a

real experiment that is brought to you by merck 
kgaa darmstadt germany. Now the most exciting

thing about this survey in my opinion is that you 
can see what everybody else has responded with in

real time so you can actually see if you're more 
optimistic or pessimistic than everyone else who

has completed this survey. I'll tell you if 
I was pessimistic or optimistic at the end,

but for now I would super appreciate it if 
you could go and fill out this survey. I

will put a link in the description as well. 
But I love surveys and this one is actually

very beautifully designed and you learn a little 
bit about yourself and other people too. The

purpose of the survey is to learn more about how 
we've all progressed over the past year and a half

to consider things like: What are the unexpected 
things that you found out about yourself?

One of the main things that I discovered from 
this whole experiment is that when I was leaving,

I was so focused on my work life. I was 
thinking, would I be productive? Would I

procrastinate? Would I be able to get things 
done in random airbnbs? And I was just so

focused on output of my work that I hadn't given 
much time to think about my mental state or

the quality of my work. And something that I 
discovered was how adaptable I am. For starters,

I could make a video anywhere using any 
equipment and it was fine. I'm not sure

if you even noticed! And then the second thing 
was how much i'm sensitive to my surroundings,

so first of all how much i'm creatively influenced 
by them. I'm sure that you noticed that in all of

my work this year where I was making videos about 
crystals and the crystal capital of the world, and

I was making videos about a wild west pharmacy 
when I was in the middle of the desert. All

while communicating with my fact checker 
in Canada and my editor in Portugal. And

I was so sensitive to the beauty that 
was around me, but also being outside

I felt like I was in such a good mood this entire 
time and the light had so much to do with it.

Working from anywhere, while it can be quite 
intense between work constant travel and

essentially living out of a suitcase, it is a 
privileged lifestyle. Not having to be confined

to a specific workspace and working from a 
space of your choosing is an advantage that

many people can't access because of the nature 
of their job. For my life this experiment was

extreme and I recognise that not everybody 
watching has the privilege or the job or the

resources to be able to do it. But there are small 
changes that you can make in your everyday life

to realise these benefitsL spending at just 
20 minutes in nature can lower your cortisol

or stress levels. Boredom is a mental state 
that allows new ideas to come to fruition.

You can move your desk into the light to try 
to get more natural sunlight in your everyday.

Ut took a complete disorder for 
me to make a change and progress.

But we can all nudge our routines towards moments 
of boredom and wonder and creativity, you never

know how much fun you'll have, what problems 
you'll solve, or just how pleasant work can be.

Progress comes in all shapes and sizes and 
human progress can change how we think.

It can change the function of our brain. 
I've certainly gone outside my comfort zone

with creative projects in the last year that i 
certainly would not have normally done before

it changes the wiring in your brain and gets 
you a little more creative at work as well.

Thank you again to Merck kgaa darmstadt 
germany for sponsoring this video. If you

have not done the human progress survey 
yet there's a link here and it's in the

description. It's a really cool design, please 
go check it out – I would super appreciate it!
